entity: Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia
entity_raw_name: Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia
section_title: Economic and social development in Western Asia

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

22.1	The Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia (ESCWA) is responsible for promoting inclusive and sustainable development in the Arab region. The mandate derives from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly and Economic and Social Council resolutions and decisions, including Council resolution 1818 (LV), by which the Commission was established, and resolution 1985/69, by which its terms of reference were amended to emphasize its social functions. The Commission’s membership includes 21 Arab member States.

22.2	The adoption of the Pact for the Future (see General Assembly resolution 79/1) provides a crucial opportunity to redefine the trajectory of the Arab region, which, notwithstanding its potential and human capital, is still not on track to implement the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and achieve all its Sustainable Development Goals. The development gains achieved to date continue to be jeopardized by conflict, which, in some cases, has set back decades-long progress; political instability and social unrest; governance, social and economic challenges; and the impact of a changing climate on ecosystems. The Pact for the Future offers the region another chance to harness artificial intelligence, digital innovation and predictive analytics, in line with the Global Digital Compact, to address the complex and interrelated challenges that it faces, including economic volatility, social inequalities, conflict and the impacts of climate change, and to take decisive action towards achieving the aspirations of the people of the Arab region for a prosperous future for all. Given its regional mandate, ESCWA is uniquely positioned to support national development trajectories and priorities by leveraging its expertise, toolkits and partnerships, in support of jointly owned development solutions and outcomes. The support delivered by the Commission to member States is also provided through the regular programme of technical cooperation and Development Account projects.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

22.3	The Commission’s programme of work for 2026 remains guided by universal principles and rights, aligned with its mandates and centred around tailored and timely support to member States in their efforts to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. To deliver on this commitment, ESCWA will continue to provide evidence-based, novel policy options, underpinned by analysis made possible by its suite of interactive, data-driven modelling and policy simulation tools and knowledge repositories; to provide technical advice and enhance human and institutional capacities, including through peer-to-peer exchanges and the promotion of South-South and interregional collaboration; to leverage its convening role to promote inclusive dialogue at the national, subregional and intraregional and interregional levels and forge consensus on viable development solutions; and to advocate for whole-of-government and whole-of-society approaches to accelerate progress against the Goals and their targets, while championing the region’s perspective through a global lens. The programme of work remains focused on high-impact interventions as means of achieving inclusive and equitable development outcomes, which address the specific needs of groups in vulnerable situations, including women, young people, older persons, persons with disabilities and the diverse and specific challenges of least developed and middle-income countries and countries in conflict, in line with the Doha Programme of Action for the Least Developed Countries for the decade 2022–2031.

22.4	As defined by the objectives of the six subprogrammes, the Commission’s programme of work remains focused on areas such as climate action and the integrated management of water resources; the transition to new and renewable sources of energy, sustainable food systems and circular economy approaches; multidimensional poverty reduction and inclusive social protection; social and gender justice, women’s economic empowerment and improved access to labour markets, as part of the commitment to “leave no one behind”; macroeconomic, fiscal and trade policies, competitiveness of business environments and opportunities for small and medium-sized enterprises; improved access to innovative sources of development finance and sustainable debt management; information technology and statistics; the transparency and accessibility of public institutions, including through digitization; innovation and digital transformation; and governance, the assessment and mitigation of transboundary risks, including conflict, and boosting the effectiveness and efficiency of public administration.

22.5	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, ESCWA will sustain its strategic partnership with the League of Arab States, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development/Development Assistance Committee and other intergovernmental organizations, as well as the Islamic Development Bank, the Arab Fund for Economic and Social Development and other relevant financial institutions. It will also promote South-South and triangular cooperation and further enhance its outreach to academic institutions and think tanks, civil society organizations and the private sector. New partnership opportunities will also be pursued as a means of expanding the range of the Commission’s support to member States, including by facilitating access to innovation, new technologies and funding opportunities.

22.6	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, as outlined in General Assembly resolution 72/279, the Commission will continue to discharge its role as co-coordinator of the Regional Collaborative Platform for Arab States and its subsidiary issue-based coalitions. It will also work closely with the Development Coordination Office, the resident coordinator offices of the United Nations, United Nations country teams, the World Bank, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and the United Nations Industrial Development Organization to ensure that any support that it provides to member States is relevant, timely and effective and fully aligned with the commitments outlined within the national United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Frameworks, while avoiding duplication of interventions and gaps.
22.7	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Sufficient opportunities for protecting and leveraging development gains for further progress towards the implementation of the 2030 Agenda exist, notwithstanding the volatile global, regional and national landscapes and increased need for urgent humanitarian action and peacebuilding efforts;
(b)	Member States remain engaged and committed to collaborating on a range of sustainable development initiatives, with a focus on transboundary issues and emerging challenges;

(c)	Development partners remain committed to collaboration on and the joint implementation of development initiatives, including their prioritization, the identification of innovative solutions and opportunities for specific contributions;

(d)	The Commission’s operational preparedness and adaptability enable it to maintain business continuity, also during times of compromised safety and security emerging from conflict, political and social instability and/or natural disasters.

22.8	ESCWA integrates a gender perspective into its activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. This includes the provision of support to its member States in developing inclusive, gender-sensitive policy frameworks to address a wide range of economic and social issues and in enhancing the capacities of national institutions and actors, as well as the development of publications and technical materials specific to advancing gender equality and women’s economic empowerment in the region. The Commission’s commitment to gender equality remains in line with the United Nations global accountability framework, in accordance with Economic and Social Council resolution 2023/11.

22.9	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, ESCWA will continue to make policy recommendations available to member States and advocate in favour of the adoption of national frameworks that promote the greater inclusion and empowerment of persons with disabilities, including enhanced access to labour markets and basic social services.

22.10	ESCWA will integrate issues related to older persons and young people across its programme of work with the aim of augmenting their role as active contributors to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. In this context the Commission will: (a) promote their meaningful participation and inclusion in development dialogues; (b) generate and disseminate knowledge essential for the development of policies that are responsive to the needs of young people and older persons; (c) facilitate peer-to-peer learning among member States within the region and beyond; and (d) support member States in the adoption and implementation of polices that protect the rights of young people and older persons.

children.text: Evaluation activities
22.13	The following evaluations completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Office of Internal Oversight Services synthesis review of evaluation results for regional economic commissions – contributions to economic development;
(b)	Midterm assessment conducted by ESCWA of a project on climate resilience through regional cooperation for inclusive sustainable development.

22.14	In response to the results of the internal evaluation referenced above, the Commission will further enhance its interventions related to climate change by leveraging technological advances for enhanced capacity-building and knowledge dissemination and by strengthening and customizing stakeholders’ engagement and ownership utilization of outputs. In addition, the Commission will strengthen its assessment of the outcomes of its economic development activities, including through beneficiary surveys of training sessions and the monitoring of policies or action taken by policymakers.
22.15	In 2026, the Commission will conduct an internal evaluation of one of its six subprogrammes.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Climate change and natural resource sustainability
Objective
22.16	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance climate action and integrated and sustainable policies in the areas of water, energy and food security.
Strategy
22.17	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Deploy in-house expertise and collaborate with other United Nations entities and external experts to analyse and assess the impact of trends and challenges and disseminate knowledge products pertaining to issues such as transboundary and the integrated management of water resources; land degradation and biodiversity; extractive industries and energy transitions; equitable, resilient, inclusive and sustainable agrifood systems; the transition to circular economy approaches; sand and dust storms; climate adaptation and mitigation; and a means for assessing climate finance and data-driven knowledge platforms related to climate resilience;

(b)	Provide technical and policy advice and expertise to member States and strengthen capacities at the regional, national and sectoral levels to use evidence and tools to identify and operationalize solutions and mainstream considerations related to climate change, sustainable natural resource management and food security into national development plans and budgets, and identify opportunities for financing climate action and adaptation;

(c)	Convene intergovernmental platforms and technical bodies to facilitate cross-sectoral dialogue, consensus-building and peer-to-peer exchanges among policymakers, practitioners, experts, civil society and other development partners from within and outside the region to promote cooperation and coordination; foster consensus towards the development of national, transboundary and regional normative frameworks on the sustainable management of water, energy and land resources; facilitate the transition to circular economy approaches; and increase access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy;

(d)	Advocate with national Governments, regional intergovernmental bodies and relevant stakeholders, including through supporting the integrated, regional reporting on and monitoring of progress against specific Sustainable Development Goal targets; promote joint solutions and the harmonization of positions; and leverage partnerships in support of the implementation and financing of such commitments.
22.18	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	The adoption by member States of national policy frameworks and regional agreements related to climate action and the sustainable use and management of natural resources; reduced emissions; making the transition away from fossil fuels in energy systems in a just, orderly and equitable manner; resilient food systems supported by sustainable agriculture; and improved climate resilience;
(b)	Strengthened cooperation on issues outlined in paragraph 22.17 above, supported by inclusive networks and participatory coordination mechanisms.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States are better equipped to prepare the next round of nationally determined contributions for climate action

22.19	The next round of nationally determined contributions under the Paris Agreement are due in 2025. The subprogramme provided member States with technical assistance on the structure of their climate finance flows, training on adaptation costing, tools for reducing risks in the deployment of renewable energy and tailored data sets to inform climate action plans. During 2024, best practices for mainstreaming water, energy and food security into nationally determined contributions were shared during five regional forums convened or co-convened by ESCWA. The aim was to empower member States to broaden sector and stakeholder engagement in nationally determined contribution preparation and to articulate evidence-based adaptation programmes alongside mitigation goals. By the end of 2024, three member States (Iraq, Lebanon and Tunisia) benefited from improved capacity and tailored knowledge products to prepare their next round of nationally determined contributions.

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: sustainable transition to new and renewable sources of energy underpinned by a transformed extractive industries sector – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

22.21	The subprogramme’s work contributed to advancing national dialogues in two member States (Jordan and Saudi Arabia) on the transformation of the extractive energy sector, which did not meet the planned target of member States formulating national policy frameworks in support of transforming the extractive energy sector with a view to making the transition to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy systems. The target was not met owing to liquidity-related constraints, which resulted in the lack of sufficient and dedicated resources for activities such as the organization of consultations at the national level and the production of national case studies.

children.text: Result 3: member States identify joint priority action to combat sand and dust storms – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.25	Sand and dust storms are an urgent transboundary challenge in Western Asia owing to climate change, land degradation and water scarcity. The subprogramme enhanced the capacity of member States to monitor and mitigate sand and dust storms, including through training, by making available geospatial mapping tools and assessments of the projected change in their frequency and intensity and by fostering knowledge exchange through the United Nations Coalition on Combating Sand and Dust Storms.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.26	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the transboundary nature of sand and dust storms required coordinated response measures at the intraregional and interregional levels. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will conduct policy dialogues in collaboration with the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific that will coincide with the launch of the United Nations Decade on Combating Sand and Dust Storms (2025–2034). This will foster common understanding among member States in Western and Central Asia to inform the joint identification of priority interventions aimed at enhancing preparedness and collaborative planning to mitigate sand and dust storms.
22.27	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (table 22.5).

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Gender justice, population and inclusive development
Objective

22.29	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to achieve equitable and inclusive social development and reduced inequality, poverty and unemployment in line with the principle of leaving no one behind.
Strategy
22.30	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Develop knowledge products and policy options and solutions, underpinned by the analysis of trends and challenges, international norms and regional perspectives on a wide range of issues pertaining to social inclusion and protection; social and gender justice; poverty reduction; labour market needs; migration; and the socioeconomic participation and empowerment of women, young people, older persons and persons with disabilities, especially those in vulnerable situations;

(b)	Support mandated reviews against global commitments and agreements; provide technical and policy advice; and strengthen national capacities to assess existing policy and legislative frameworks, to identify and operationalize viable legislation and solutions and to mainstream the reduction in inequalities and equal participation, protection and specific needs of those in vulnerable situations into national development plans and budgets;
(c)	Enhance existing and develop new methodologies, regional public goods and interactive tools for simulation and analysis of policy options and their impact on inclusive development trajectories;

(d)	Engage member States and development stakeholders in dialogue to advocate for the adoption of policy solutions and to forge consensus on issues outlined in paragraph 22.30 (a) above, while promoting South-South (intraregional and interregional) collaboration and peer learning.
22.31	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	National policy frameworks and strategies adopted by member States to address structural inequalities and promote social justice and greater social inclusion and the socioeconomic empowerment and participation of women, young people, older persons, persons with disabilities and migrants, especially those in vulnerable situations;

(b)	Enhanced coverage of the peoples of the region, in particular persons in vulnerable situations, through social protection and poverty eradication programmes and their improved access to decent and equitable employment opportunities.
Programme performance in 2024
Reaffirmed commitment to the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action

22.32	Periodic reviews of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action allow countries to measure progress against commitments and to reflect on challenges and opportunities that affect full implementation. The subprogramme encouraged all Arab member States to engage in the current iteration of the review, which marked the thirtieth anniversary of the adoption of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action.

22.33	The subprogramme provided technical expertise and capacity-building support to 10 of the 18 member States that conducted the review, including the facilitation of national-level consultations with lawmakers, civil society representatives, the private sector and academic institutions. During 2024, the subprogramme supported member States in finalizing their national reports and co-led, together with the League of Arab States and the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (UN-Women), a regional-level review to identify key achievements and measures undertaken over the past five years to address challenges in implementing the 12 critical areas of the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action. Furthermore, the subprogramme facilitated negotiations among member States, which led to the adoption of a regional declaration reaffirming their commitment to the Beijing Declaration and Platform for Action.
22.34	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 22.7).
Table 22.7

children.text: Result 3: member States leverage machine learning to forecast budget needs for social assistance programming – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.39	Financial allocations received by Governments of developing countries to establish social assistance programmes are often ad hoc, and the level of support is determined by donors on the basis of their relevant priorities and budget availability and not on government estimates of social assistance needs. The subprogramme conducted studies to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of current social protection systems and programmes, supported in part by machine learning-aided statistical analysis.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.40	The lesson for the subprogramme was that increased data availability and enhanced database interoperability in the region’s middle- and low-income countries provided fertile ground for developing and institutionalizing machine learning-based applications in support of ministries’ ability to forecast social assistance budget needs. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will assess the feasibility of such applications, including data exchange and coding requirements. The subprogramme will also develop and institutionalize a tailored machine learning-based forecasting application for member States.

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Shared economic prosperity
Objective

22.43	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to achieve equitable economic growth, amplify regional interconnectedness and integration, and advance the effective implementation of the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development in support of the 2030 Agenda.
Strategy
22.44	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Develop and provide knowledge products and evidence for policymaking related to trade, logistics and transport, including regional integration; the application of behavioural science in development, public policy monitoring and evaluation systems; economic diversification and macroeconomic stability; debt sustainability and fiscal policies as a means of enhancing investment in sustainable development priorities; and financing for development, including integrated national financing frameworks;

(b)	Enhance existing and develop new dynamic, data-driven policy simulation tools (anchored in artificial intelligence and machine learning approaches) pertaining to trade flows, taxation, debt optimization, debt swaps, social expenditure, the monitoring and evaluation of development plans and contextualized economic modelling, and promote the application of modern technologies to facilitate trade and logistics;

(c)	Make available to its member States policy advice and technical expertise and strengthen capacities to deploy behavioural insights and modelling and impact simulation tools in support of decision-making and policy development processes aimed at providing immediate, medium- and long-term solutions to national development challenges in the areas identified in paragraph 22.44 (a) above;

(d)	Promote collaboration, coordination and the exchange of good practice; and foster consensus on priorities and joint initiatives aimed at improving regional integration, facilitating trade, promoting innovative debt solutions and enhancing fiscal space and financing for sustainable development initiatives.
22.45	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Evidence-backed development planning; member States adopting policy frameworks to address structural economic challenges; improved debt management and sustainability; enhanced equity, efficiency and effectiveness of public spending and budgeting, including on national development priorities; new trade opportunities and economic diversification, including enhanced operational environment for small and medium-sized enterprises; and the creation of fiscal space for social investment in basic social services and the achievement of sustainable development goals;

(b)	Increased contribution of small and medium-sized enterprises to national and regional economies and greater economic participation and empowerment of individuals, including those in vulnerable situations.
Programme performance in 2024
Tunisia develops a climate/Sustainable Development Goals debt swap programme

22.46	Amid the challenges of rising debt and debt servicing, the global economic slowdown, persistent trade deficits and climate change, financing for sustainable development and climate action are becoming increasingly difficult. Considering pressures on public budgets and financing gaps, mobilizing funding without adding more debt is a priority. The ESCWA climate/the Sustainable Development Goals debt swap initiative supports member States in developing programme-based debt swaps towards enhancing fiscal space to finance climate action and the Goals. Building on the previous achievements of the initiative, the subprogramme supported Tunisia in operationalizing an inter-agency task force mandated with the development of a climate/Goals debt swap programme, including a priority list of projects, for negotiation with creditors. The projects were to contribute to achieving nationally determined contribution priority action in areas such as water, energy and the environment, while addressing climate and socioeconomic vulnerabilities. Specifically, in 2024 the subprogramme promoted an inclusive, intersectoral platform approach and provided technical expertise and advice, including on the establishment of key performance indicators for impact assessments at the project and programme levels, which also facilitated the prioritization of projects.

Performance measure

children.text: Result 3: member States reach bilateral trade agreements beyond the region – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.52	External trade is one of the key factors that underpin sustainable economic development and diversification. Therefore, national frameworks governing it ought to align with these long-term objectives, which are crucial for achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. The subprogramme developed the Arab trade simulator interface to support evidence-based decision-making regarding trade opportunities as a first step to developing tailored national interfaces.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.53	The lesson learned for the subprogramme was that more tailored analyses for individual member States was needed to reflect specificities of domestic economic models and priorities against the backdrop of global economic and trade indicators. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will develop national global economy-wide trade simulator interfaces, customized for each member State, which will empower users in testing and evaluating alternative trade policies and enabling preconditions at the national, regional and global levels. The subprogramme will also develop the skills and capacities of civil servants to enable them to better negotiate trade offers.

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Statistics, the information society and technology
Objective

22.56	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to strengthen the development of official statistical frameworks, improve the quality and availability of statistics and advance the information society by accelerating the integration of technology and innovation for sustainable development in the Arab region.
Strategy
22.57	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Develop methodologies and tools to enhance the capacities of national statistical systems to implement and adapt to evolving international statistical standards, methodologies and best practices, and promote the integration of innovative data sources and geostatistical information;

(b)	In line with global and regional processes, such as the Global Digital Compact and WSIS+20, develop knowledge products, models, toolkits and platforms and enhance the capacity of policymakers and practitioners in member States to produce evidence and, on that basis, develop digital policy frameworks and strategies aimed at enhancing digital infrastructure, digital transformation, digital economy, digital government and e-accessibility, in support of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda;

(c)	Enhance national capacities to produce and utilize quality statistics and data for evidence-based policymaking and provide technical support for the adoption of policy frameworks, statistical methodologies and strategies to harness emerging technologies and innovative solution for monitoring and reporting on sustainable development indicators, in line with national plans and priorities, and increase the value created from statistics, geospatial-enabled data, digitization and emerging technologies;

(d)	Convene intergovernmental and technical, multi-stakeholder forums to foster consensus and facilitate dialogue and exchanges, with the aim of promoting cooperation, partnerships and coordination and incentivizing investment in advancing both digital development and transformation and the production of quality statistics and data.
22.58	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	An enhanced value chain of timely, accessible, interoperable and integrated data from diverse sources, including geolocated and disaggregated data, that is compliant with international statistical standards;

(b)	Member States developing, adopting and implementing enhanced policy frameworks pertaining to digital and emerging technologies, as a means of accelerating the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.
Programme performance in 2024
Djibouti and Jordan apply modernized approaches to censuses

22.59	Statistical information obtained through censuses remains a core reference for the analysis and interpretation of evidence, and the accuracy, efficiency and timeliness of the data that it yields is therefore critical. During 2024, the subprogramme provided member States with technical expertise and advice on the design and conduct of national censuses, including the deployment of modern technology and the digitization of data collection (Djibouti) and the piloting of a multi-source methodology that would enable a register-based census (Jordan). Concurrently, the subprogramme organized study tours, which promoted peer-to-peer exchanges between Djibouti and Egypt and between Jordan and Oman, and resulted in enhanced capacities of national statistical offices in Djibouti and Jordan to apply modernized approaches to data collection, further enhancing quality and compliance with international standards. Furthermore, Egypt’s Central Agency for Public Mobilization and Statistics supported the Institut de la statistique de Djibouti by providing 1,400 tablets for a digitized census.
22.60	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 22.17).

children.text: Result 3: Arab member States, including least developed countries, produce external trade statistics – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.65	The availability of trade statistics is essential for effective economic policymaking. However, such statistics remain unavailable for 6 of 21 ESCWA member States, including 3 Arab least developed countries. The subprogramme has been estimating trade data for these countries to address gaps in the external trade statistics database for the Arab region.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.66	The lesson for the subprogramme was twofold: (a) the data estimates, while used regionally, could not be incorporated into the global United Nations Comtrade Database to close the data gap for better-informed decision-making; and (b) there were risks related to the sustainability of the continued replacement of official statistics by estimates. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will collaborate with member States to enhance their capacity in internationally agreed frameworks for the compilation of and reporting on international trade statistics, alternative methodologies and programming skills. In addition, the peer-to-peer exchange of knowledge will be facilitated through study tours, to further empower the targeted countries to produce trade statistics independently.

children.text: Subprogramme 5 – 2030 Agenda and SDG coordination
Objective

22.69	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to accelerate progress towards sustainable development in the Arab region in line with the 2030 Agenda and to advance intraregional collaboration and a multi-stakeholder approach to key regional and subregional sustainable development issues.
Strategy
22.70	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Advocate with a diverse set of stakeholders, including policymakers, the private sector, academic institutions and civil societies, for principled action towards the implementation of the 2030 Agenda, in particular in line with the commitment to “leave no one behind” and a people-centred approach to development, and leverage a broad range of partnerships, including with the private sector and financial institutions, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations, civil society, and academic institutions and think tanks, to promote a whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach;

(b)	Develop and disseminate knowledge products underpinned by the analysis of member States’ progress towards the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and its principles, including gaps in policy frameworks, and promote transformative development solutions for accelerating inclusive, sustainable development in the region;

(c)	Convene and ensure ongoing support for and follow-up on various platforms, in connection with the Arab Forum for Sustainable Development, to facilitate multi-stakeholder engagement and dialogue and peer-to-peer exchanges; to foster consensus on sustainable development priorities and action; to promote subregional, interregional and intraregional (South-South) and triangular collaboration and coordination; and to support cross-sectoral cooperation and alignment of national development priorities and plans with both the 2030 Agenda and resources available for their implementation;

(d)	Enhance capacities to conduct integrated monitoring and reporting, at the local, national and regional levels, of the progress against specific Sustainable Development Goal targets, including through the building of national and institutional capacity to conduct voluntary national reviews and the identification of policy gaps; identify and disseminate innovative policy solutions and recommendations; ensure that the region’s perspective is reflected through a global lens; and foster cross-sectoral coordination of the Commission’s support to member States’ efforts to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.
22.71	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Enhanced commitment of policymakers and practitioners, regional intergovernmental organizations, the private sector, including financial institutions, academia and think tanks, and civil society organizations in the Arab region to the principles of the 2030 Agenda;

(b)	The adoption by member States and development stakeholders of a more participatory, whole-of-government and whole-of-society approach to the implementation of and follow-up on Sustainable Development Goal priorities and related action;

(c)	Improved utilization by member States and development stakeholders of available dialogue and advocacy platforms as a means of promoting consensus, peer-to-peer learning and coordination at the national, subregional, intraregional, interregional and global levels; and mobilizing sustained, targeted financing for an accelerated implementation of the 2030 Agenda;

(d)	Improved capacity of policymakers and other stakeholders to identify policy gaps and related policy opportunities and solutions and take action to advance the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened local governance for development through the first iteration of the Arab Mayors Academy

22.72	The Arab region faces a critical gap in capacity-building for local authorities, limiting their ability to align with global agendas such as the 2030 Agenda, the New Urban Agenda and the Pact for the Future. The subprogramme partnered with the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat) and United Cities and Local Governments to launch the Arab Mayors Academy, the first regional learning initiative, collaboratively designed with local authorities. The initiative was set up as a network of Arab city leaders and global development stakeholders to empower local governance and catalyse resilience and sustainability in cities throughout the region. In 2024, the first iteration of the Academy gathered experts from more than 20 global entities, including international organizations, non-governmental organizations, academia and the private sector, to offer 11 senior city officials a hybrid curriculum, primarily in Arabic, focusing on the localization of the Sustainable Development Goals, emergency preparedness, smart sustainable cities, quality of life in cities, climate resilience, urban financing, partnerships and diplomacy, among others. Moreover, the online discussions component was open to the broader public, reaching more than 80 representatives of local authorities on each occasion.
22.73	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 22.22).

children.text: Result 3: member States identify and address policy gaps linked to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.78	Arab countries’ modest progress on achieving the Sustainable Development Goals highlights the need to evaluate the adequacy of national policies and capacities for policy assessment and reform. The subprogramme strengthened the regional knowledge base on Goals-related policy frameworks, including by analysing regional trends and gaps in design and implementation, and provided a platform for knowledge exchange on the 2030 Agenda follow-up and review.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.79	The lesson for the subprogramme was that, to drive the policy change necessary to accelerate progress in the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals, the subprogramme needed to provide capacity-building support for strengthening the analytical quality of national follow-up and review processes. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will enhance the skills and capacities of Goals coordination teams in member States to lead cross-sectoral policy assessments and identify national Goals policy gaps and solutions. The subprogramme will also restructure its dialogue platform to ensure the more inclusive participation of relevant stakeholders and improve their access to global and regional good practices in the area.
22.80	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 22.25).

children.text: Subprogramme 6 – Governance and conflict prevention
Objective

22.82	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to advance just, peaceful and inclusive societies, especially for people living under occupation or in conflict or post-conflict settings; to improve governance and strengthen effective, efficient and accountable public institutions; and to enhance service delivery.
Strategy
22.83	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Generate and make available evidence-based policy analysis and recommendations to member States and relevant stakeholders, grounded in the principle of a human development approach, with a focus on mitigating the impact of conflict and occupation on the capacity to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals, facilitating national recovery and improving governance and institutional capacities to deliver basic services and respond to shocks; strengthening regional cooperation on governance and public administration; and boosting the competitiveness of the business environment, including consumer protection mechanisms;

(b)	Provide technical expertise, methodologies and tools while enhancing capacities to identify and operationalize immediate, medium- and long-term solutions, aimed at pre-emptively addressing emerging socioeconomic, environmental and governance challenges and conflicts; enhancing prevention, recovery and development planning; improving transparency and accessibility and the efficiency of State-run services; and reinforcing competition policies and consumer protection mechanisms that uphold fair market practices and improve transparency;

(c)	Foster South-South (intraregional and interregional) and triangular cooperation and build consensus on the priorities and action required to minimize the impact of conflict and any sudden shocks, inter alia, on the ability of member States to advance their national development agendas;

(d)	Support the five Arab least developed countries, within the framework of the Doha Programme of Action (2022–2031), by strengthening their institutional capacities for implementing the 2030 Agenda and graduating from the least developed countries category;

(e)	Enhance the capabilities of Palestinian institutions to mitigate the adverse effects of the Israeli occupation on development, including by supporting national recovery efforts and capacities in the Occupied Palestinian Territory and reducing the asymmetric dependency of its economy.
22.84	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	Improved understanding and prevention of development challenges associated with sudden shocks, including conflict, and effective mitigation of their impact on national development and recovery trajectories;
(b)	More effective public institutions, in particular in the five Arab least developed countries, with enhanced capabilities to deliver basic services in a transparent, accessible and inclusive way;
(c)	Operationalization of a contextualized, people-centred approach to development planning and policy formulation;
(d)	A more competitive and transparent business environment and more effective consumer protection mechanisms.
Programme performance in 2024
Oman operationalizes an integrated and evidence-based national development planning framework

22.85	As part of its effort to advance public policy across the Arab region, including by promoting effective governance and sustainable development, the subprogramme supported Oman in conducting a midterm assessment of its tenth five-year national development plan (2021–2025). The assessment evaluated economic, governance, social and environmental performance and tracked progress on 430 work programmes, 3,200 activities and 150 key performance indicators and their alignment with Oman Vision 2040 and the 2030 Agenda. Specifically, in order to foster transparency and stakeholder engagement, the subprogramme developed a dynamic platform that allowed Oman’s 55 implementing entities to update data by priority, strategic goal, activity and key performance indicator, enhancing accountability and proactive problem-solving. This was followed by a facilitated consultative process, during which the assessment results served as a basis for the identification of challenges and opportunities for accelerating the plan’s implementation. The support culminated in Oman identifying ways to enhance implementation and guide planning as it embarked on defining its next five-year development plan.

children.text: Result 3: member States develop and deploy development policies resilient to fragility and sudden shocks – Proposed programme plan for 2026

22.91	By 2023, some 76.8 million people across seven Arab countries in conflict or post-conflict settings (16.3 per cent of the region’s population) required humanitarian assistance. The subprogramme launched a regional initiative to foster transitions towards durable peace and development through a combined evidence-based and consensus-building approach that aligned national priorities in humanitarian, development and peacebuilding fields.
Lessons learned and planned change

22.92	The lesson for the subprogramme was that building resilience and enabling sustainable recovery required targeted capacity-building to enable the public sector to effectively deliver services and foster trust. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will enhance its capacity-building support to public institutions and other relevant national stakeholders to enable the design of policies that are resilient and adaptable to crises. In parallel, the Commission will engage member States and United Nations resident coordinators to develop operational frameworks and national implementation strategies that more effectively integrate humanitarian, development and peace efforts, thereby facilitating smoother transitions toward recovery and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Other changes

22.98	As shown in table 22.35 (1), resource changes reflect a net increase of $10,600, representing an increase under contractual services reflecting a higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of United Nations Headquarters; the other changes, which include the upgrade of a P-4 post to a P-5 post and the redeployment of post and non-post resources between executive direction and management and programme support, are overall cost-neutral. The details of other changes are as follows:

(a)	Executive direction and management. The net increase of $4,794,900 relates mainly to the proposed redeployment of the Conference Management Section as the Knowledge Management Service under executive direction and management, entailing the following:
(i)	The inward redeployment of 30 posts (1 P-5, 6 P-4, 4 P-3, 1 National Professional Officer and 18 Local level) from programme support, as reflected in annex II to the present report ($4,232,400);

(ii)	The inward redeployment of requirements under travel ($8,500), contractual services ($207,900), general operating expenses ($25,800) and furniture and equipment ($17,200) to consolidate and streamline the content delivery and knowledge management capacity of the Commission, including intellectual support and language, documentation and conference services under the component. Justification for the proposed redeployment is provided in annex I to the present report;

(iii)	Increased requirements under other staff costs ($127,000), consultants ($33,800) and contractual services ($190,100) reflect mainly the need to strengthen the capacity to design, develop and maintain specialized data solutions for member States;

(iv)	The increased requirements under experts ($100,000) to provide for high-level expert group meetings in support of the decision support system and data science and of the small and medium-sized enterprise forum;

(v)	The aforementioned increases are offset in part by the outward redeployment of one post of Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) to programme support, as reflected in annex II ($147,800);

(b)	Subprogramme 1, Climate change and natural resources. The decrease of $50,000 under experts relates to the anticipated streamlining of activities into interrelated events and back-to-back meetings;

(c)	Subprogramme 2, Gender justice, population, and inclusive development. The net decrease of $48,800 relates to reduced requirements under experts ($50,000) and travel of staff ($14,900), reflecting the anticipated streamlining of activities into interrelated events and back-to-back meetings, offset in part by the increased requirements under contractual services ($16,100), reflecting higher anticipated requirements for the development of enhanced and customized technical tools on gender justice, poverty reduction and social protection;

(d)	Subprogramme 4, Statistics, the information society and technology. The increase ($23,100) under contractual services reflects the anticipated increase in the requirements for individual contractors to strengthen capacity in price statistics, digital development and statistical support to ensure the delivery of high-quality data and technical expertise for key initiatives;

(e)	Subprogramme 6, Governance and conflict prevention. The net decrease ($25,600) relates to reduced requirements under consultants ($43,100), reflecting the leveraging of technology solutions, such as data analytics, artificial intelligence and collaborative platforms, to streamline processes and analysis required for decision-making, offset in part by the increased requirements under contractual services ($17,500), reflecting higher anticipated requirements for enhanced and customized technical and policy tools that will provide specialized expertise in conflict prevention and recovery, institution-building, sustainable development in post-conflict settings, competition reforms in trade policy and human development, ensuring the effective delivery of the ESCWA mandate;
(f)	Programme support. The net decrease of $4,683,000 relates to:

(i)	The outward redeployment of 30 posts (1 P-5, 6 P-4, 4 P-3, 1 National Professional Officer and 18 Local level) to the Knowledge Management Service under executive direction and management ($4,232,400), as reflected in annex II;

(ii)	The outward redeployment of the requirements under travel of staff ($8,500), contractual services ($207,900), general operating expenses ($25,800) and furniture and equipment ($17,200) to consolidate and streamline the content delivery and knowledge management capacity, including intellectual support and language, documentation and conference services under executive direction and management;

(iii)	Reduced requirements under general operating expenses ($427,100), reflecting mainly the anticipated decrease in energy use in the ESCWA building, including through the optimization of the heating, ventilation and air-conditioning systems and the adoption of energy-efficient lighting and other smart building management systems;
(iv)	Offset in part by the following:
a.	The upward reclassification of one post of Medical Officer (P-4) to Senior Medical Officer (P-5) ($32,500), as reflected in annex II;
b.	The inward redeployment of one post of Programme Management Officer (National Professional Officer) from executive direction and management ($147,800), as reflected in annex II;
c.	Increased requirements under other staff costs ($45,000), reflecting the need to strengthen the capacity to design, develop and maintain specialized data solutions for member States;
d.	Increased requirements under contractual services ($10,600) relating to a higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of Headquarters.
Extrabudgetary resources

22.99	As reflected in tables 22.33 (2) and 22.34 (2), extrabudgetary resources amount to $12,442,800. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 45 posts (1 D-1, 1 P-5, 3 P-4, 3 P-3, 1 P-2, 4 National Professional Officer and 32 Local level) to perform various functions, including in the areas of economic development, sustainable development, administration and coordination. In addition, non-post resources would be used for strengthening data and information capabilities, promoting coordinated multisectoral interventions in such areas as energy, agriculture and food systems, water, gender equality, job creation and youth empowerment, decision support and data science, establishing portals and platforms for the Sustainable Development Goals to support the Arab region’s digital revolution, enhancing initiatives in sustainable energy transitions, social protection, economic empowerment of persons with disabilities, and training programmes for artificial intelligence technologies and business models. In essence, the funds are intended to boost the region’s capacity for sustainable development through improved data, coordination and targeted initiatives across various sectors, with a strong focus on digital transformation and modern technologies such as artificial intelligence.
22.100	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the secretariat of ESCWA, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.

Executive direction and management

22.103	The Office of the Executive Secretary is responsible for coordinating and providing overall leadership, policy direction and management of the ESCWA secretariat to support member States, in collaboration with other entities of the United Nations system, with strategic analysis, policy guidelines and capacity-building activities to address key development challenges and issues and to implement innovative solutions for region-wide equitable and inclusive economic prosperity, social progress and environmental sustainability. The Office provides leadership and policy orientation and establishes criteria to coordinate follow-up in the region on implementing the 2030 Agenda and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, and the mainstreaming of cross-cutting issues, such as gender equality and the empowerment of women, and sustainability perspectives, throughout ESCWA substantive programmes. The Knowledge Management Service will provide alignment with the Commission’s strategic planning and project cycles, improving agility and responsiveness to programmatic needs. In addition, the Service will provide expertise in communication, content quality and multilingual support, reinforcing role of ESCWA as a knowledge-driven organization, while enhancing its visibility and coherence.

22.104	The role of ESCWA in supporting evidence-based policymaking and innovation, together with its commitment to the Secretary-General’s strategies on data and new technologies, will ensure that the Arab region is not only a beneficiary of the digital revolution, but also an active contributor to the global dialogue on sustainable development through technology. The Decision Support and Data Science Division will provide foresight and analysis of regional and global trends, as well as evidence pertaining to sustainable development, necessary for informed policymaking, and will bolster innovation and the roll-out of information and communications technology solutions in support of member States and the Commission’s programme delivery, including through coordination across its six subprogrammes.

22.105	The Office reinforces policy consistency and coherence and promotes effective collaboration and coordination, both within the ESCWA secretariat and among United Nations entities and development partners involved in addressing regional development issues, including through the Regional Coordination Mechanism for Arab States. It also strengthens cooperation and coordination with international and regional intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations, especially the League of Arab States and its subsidiary bodies.

22.106	The Strategy, Planning, Accountability, Results and Knowledge Section will continue to promote dynamism and innovation in the ESCWA business model and medium-term strategy and to act as a focal point for the annual results framework and related applications in Umoja. The Section will continue to be the basis for organizational learning processes, focusing on accountability and on the attainment of results, and ensuring the operational excellence of ESCWA through risk reduction and change management processes. The Section will continue to manage the broader knowledge and dissemination processes of the Commission.

22.107	The Resource Mobilization and Partnerships Section will continue to strengthen relationships with funding agencies and donors; maintain up-to-date regional and global donor mapping; coordinate and support project development, budgeting and fundraising; support and track the implementation of extrabudgetary projects; assist ESCWA cluster leaders in building and enhancing institutional partnerships (regional and global); support cluster leaders’ relationships with civil society and non-State actors and partners; and develop and negotiate legally binding partnerships and donor agreements.

22.108	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Commission integrates environmental management practices into its operations. In 2026, the Commission will: (a) facilitate dialogue and collaboration among stakeholders to foster policy coherence, knowledge-sharing and capacity-building initiatives that support the implementation of the 2030 Agenda; (b) provide technical assistance and advisory services to member States, helping to strengthen institutional frameworks, enhance data-driven decision-making and integrate sustainable development goals into national policies and strategies; and (c) promote innovative financing mechanisms and resource mobilization efforts to bridge funding gaps and support sustainable, inclusive economic growth across the region.

22.109	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 22.40. ESCWA has made efforts to raise awareness among staff of the requirement to comply with the advance purchase guidance and, in this context, has put in place a procedure whereby travel requests not compliant with the advance booking policy have to be cleared by the Office of the Executive Secretary to hold project managers accountable for the late travel-related submissions. As a result of these measures, there has been a continuous improvement in the compliance rate. The Commission will continue its efforts to achieve its targets in 2026. It will enhance compliance with advance travel booking through regular monitoring, strengthened accountability and performance benchmarking. These measures are intended to sustain improvements, promote cost-effective travel planning and ensure operational efficiency.
